docs.snippet: Lori Berenson, the New York woman whose conviction on charges of collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's highest court on Monday, will not be granted a presidential pardon, the justice minister said today.    Ms. Berenson's parents,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lori Berenson, the New York woman whose conviction on charges of collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's highest court on Monday, will not be granted a presidential pardon, the justice minister said today. Ms. Berenson's parents, Mark and Rhoda Berenson, have urged President Alejandro Toledo to pardon their daughter, who was convicted last June of aiding the Túpac Amaru rebels in their war against the government in the 1990's. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison.
docs.abstract: Lori Berenson, American woman whose conviction for collaborating with Marxist rebels was upheld by Peru's Supreme Court, will not be granted presidential pardon; Justice Min Fernando Olivera says Berenson is proven terrorist, who was convicted in new trial with all guarantees; says sentence must be served since law should be applied equally to everyone (M)

headline.main: U.S. Woman Jailed in Peru Won't Get a Presidential Pardon

docs.snippet: In the month since the collapse of the Taliban government in Afghanistan, nearly 3,500 former Taliban fighters have been held here in a prison built for 800, under conditions that are raising alarm among international aid groups.    The prisoners ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the month since the collapse of the Taliban government in Afghanistan, nearly 3,500 former Taliban fighters have been held here in a prison built for 800, under conditions that are raising alarm among international aid groups. The prisoners are being interrogated by United States investigators, but their jailer is Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, Afghanistan's new deputy defense minister and an ethnic Uzbek warlord whose reputation for brutality has been well documented over the last 20 years. Neither the Afghan authorities nor the United States forces here are saying what the prisoners' ultimate fate will be.
docs.abstract: Nearly 3,500 Taliban prisoners have been held for month in Shibarghan prison built for 800, raising concern of aid groups; photo; prisoners are being interrogated by US, but jailer is Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, Afghanistan's new deputy defense minister and ethnic Uzbek warlord with long reputation for brutality; Red Cross reports dozens of dysentery cases; other Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters are imprisoned in Kohat, Pakistan, where locals are complaining of mistreatment; US officer at Shibarghan says he has not been inside prison, but that interrogators are processing prisoners as quickly as possible, treating them with dignity (M)

headline.main: Prison Packed With Taliban Raises Concern

byline.original: By CARLOTTA GALL with MARK LANDLER

docs.snippet: RECENTLY, an American soldier approached an American reporter at Bagram Air Base, the former Soviet air field now taken over by American troops.    ''I wonder if you might press the generals for an answer,'' the soldier, a member of the Army's 10t...
docs.lead_paragraph: RECENTLY, an American soldier approached an American reporter at Bagram Air Base, the former Soviet air field now taken over by American troops. ''I wonder if you might press the generals for an answer,'' the soldier, a member of the Army's 10th Mountain Division, said. ''We really want to go home.''
docs.abstract: Many Afghans are anxious that ethnic and tribal warfare may again break out when American military finally leaves Afghanistan; Bush administration repeatedly says it intends to help Afghanistan find stability and will prevent return of chaos, but Afghans recall that this is same administration that regarded 'nation building' with contempt before Sept 11; photo (M)

headline.main: The World; The Anxiety of Postwar Afghans

docs.snippet: The adversaries in Congo's nearly four-year war met today for the first time to begin talks aimed at bringing peace and political unity to that Central African nation.    After a two-year delay, 300 representatives from the government in Kinshasa,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The adversaries in Congo's nearly four-year war met today for the first time to begin talks aimed at bringing peace and political unity to that Central African nation. After a two-year delay, 300 representatives from the government in Kinshasa, three armed rebel groups and various civic organizations arrived in this resort city in South Africa, where they are scheduled to stay 45 days for the so-called inter-Congolese dialogue.
docs.abstract: Adversaries in Congo's nearly four-year war meet for first time to begin talks aimed at bringing peace and political unity to nation; so-called inter-Congolese dialogue, held in Sun City, South Africa, includes 300 representatives from government in Kinshasa, three armed rebel groups and various civic organizations; participants are supposed to map out plans for national army, new political structure and transition to democracy; other countries involved in war are not party to talks; map (M)

headline.main: Congo Factions Gather for Peace Talks

docs.snippet: Their cells may be small and their jumpsuits an unpleasant shade of orange, but the Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners in Cuba are getting some good eats. Their meals, which the military has ensured are halal, or in keeping with Islamic law, are nearl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Their cells may be small and their jumpsuits an unpleasant shade of orange, but the Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners in Cuba are getting some good eats. Their meals, which the military has ensured are halal, or in keeping with Islamic law, are nearly identical to the MRE's (Meals Ready to Eat) given to American soldiers. A typical day's cuisine, as it might fit into the Department of Agriculture's food pyramid: MILK, YOGURT AND CHEESE GROUP Cream cheese
docs.abstract: Taliban and Al Qaeda prisoners at Guantanamo, Cuba, are being fed meals prepared in keeping with Islamic law; diagram (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Defying a Taboo, Nazi Protagonists Invade Video Games'' (Jan. 3): Adolf Hitler never played Return to Castle Wolfenstein. The commanders at concentration camps like Auschwitz did not frequent Day of Defeat servers. I point t...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Defying a Taboo, Nazi Protagonists Invade Video Games'' (Jan. 3): Adolf Hitler never played Return to Castle Wolfenstein. The commanders at concentration camps like Auschwitz did not frequent Day of Defeat servers. I point this out to remind everyone that games do not necessarily create Nazis; hateful ignorance will exist regardless of World War II-themed games. Day of Defeat began as the brainchild of creative programmers, not as the product of a conspiracy of right-wing goose-steppers out to recruit from online players. A majority of players are not head-shaven, Doc Martens-wearing thugs, but your average run-of-the-mill gaming nerds.
docs.abstract: Patrick R Todd letter on Jan 3 article holds World War II-themed computer games with Nazi emblems are not designed to advance Nazi views

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.snippet: Government and industry officials from 35 countries are meeting in Canada on new rules for combating the trade in diamonds mined in conflict zones. The conference, which ends today in Ottawa, aims to carry out a certification system to track the o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Government and industry officials from 35 countries are meeting in Canada on new rules for combating the trade in diamonds mined in conflict zones. The conference, which ends today in Ottawa, aims to carry out a certification system to track the origins and movements of diamonds and prevent the sale of the ''blood diamonds'' used to finance rebellions in Sierra Leone and Angola. A similar meeting in Botswana last November ended in disagreement over monitoring policies and possible conflicts with World Trade Organization rules. Susan Catto (NYT)
docs.abstract: Government and industry officials from 35 nations meet in Canada, seeking to implement certification system to prevent sale of 'blood diamonds' used to finance rebellions in Sierra Leone and Angola (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: Attack On Global 'Blood Diamond' Trade

docs.snippet: A National Academy of Sciences panel is backing away from its conclusion last year that the children of veterans exposed to Agent Orange may have an increased chance of developing a form of leukemia. After reviewing additional data, including a co...
docs.lead_paragraph: A National Academy of Sciences panel is backing away from its conclusion last year that the children of veterans exposed to Agent Orange may have an increased chance of developing a form of leukemia. After reviewing additional data, including a corrected Australian study, the Institute of Medicine concluded that there was not enough evidence to establish a connection between exposure and development of acute myelogenous leukemia.
docs.abstract: National Academy of Sciences panel backs away from its conclusion in 2001 that childeren of veterans exposed to Agent Orange, defoliant in used in Vietnam, may have increased chance of developing form of leukemia (S)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Cutting Agent Orange Health Tie

docs.snippet: In the Balkans, where the wars were often fought from house to house, among neighbors, candid Serbs often say, yes, our people committed war crimes, but we were not the only ones. In civil war, all are guilty.    By making NATO the focus of his ow...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the Balkans, where the wars were often fought from house to house, among neighbors, candid Serbs often say, yes, our people committed war crimes, but we were not the only ones. In civil war, all are guilty. By making NATO the focus of his own defense, Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav leader, has extended that justification a distinct notch: you in the West, he says, with your nice homes and radar-skirting bombers -- you, too, are bloodied. For two days, he presented his evidence: photo after photo of what the United States military calls ''collateral damage,'' people killed by NATO bombs.
docs.abstract: News analysis; former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic is trying to shift blame to others and to cast himself as victim by making NATO bombing focus of his defense at war crimes trial in the Hague; his defense taps into real grievances of Serbs, lack of easy solutions in Balkans and palpable misgivings among poor nations about extent of American power; photo (S)

docs.snippet: Honest Abe? Not according to Charles Hanks, Abraham Lincoln's cousin, who said Lincoln was famous for ''rowdying,'' the 19th-century version of wilding. Charles wanted to set the record straight after reading a letter supporting Lincoln's presiden...
docs.lead_paragraph: Honest Abe? Not according to Charles Hanks, Abraham Lincoln's cousin, who said Lincoln was famous for ''rowdying,'' the 19th-century version of wilding. Charles wanted to set the record straight after reading a letter supporting Lincoln's presidential bid by Charles's own brother, John Hanks. The two letters can be found at lincolnandthecivilwar.com, a new Web site that includes illustrated periodicals and presidential campaign newspapers from the 1860-1865 period. The Web site, scheduled to be online by the end of next month, is the brainchild of John Adler, who publishes HarpWeek, an electronic version of the 19th-century newspaper Harper's Weekly. His is just one of a flurry of new efforts to make original Lincoln and Civil War documents available online.
docs.abstract: Excerpts from some of Lincoln documents posted online by Library of Congress, which is cooperating with project to put all of Lincoln's presidential papers online by end of decade; photos; other sites on Lincoln and Civil War noted (M)
